awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving Undergraduate Education in Civil & Building Engineering through Student-centric Cyber-Physical Systems and Real-world Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in high quality undergraduate engineering education.  It will do so by integrating smartphone-based digital visualization technology into Civil and Building Engineering curricula. The project predicts that this addition will improve student engagement in the engineering classroom.  Education research shows that active learning increases student motivation and learning . However, active learning experiences are challenging to incorporate into civil and building engineering, because these fields address problems that are large-scale or not available locally. Additionally, students often view civil and building engineering negatively as “low-tech,” making it more challenging to interest potential majors. This project proposes a novel approach to increase enrollment, retention, and success in civil and building engineering degree programs: the use of low-cost technologies to enhance the student-learning experience.  Specifically, real-world problems in civil and building engineering will be brought into undergraduate classrooms through interactive digital visualizations of civil and building engineering systems. Students will be able to control the systems through affordable sensing technologies, such as smartphones, cameras, and Internet of Things sensors. The resulting educational tools, which the project calls student-centric cyber-physical systems, are expected to promote active learning as students interact with these systems in real-time. These tools will also introduce students to innovative sensors for smart infrastructure, which may stimulate additional interest and increase student recruitment and retention.

Through design-based implementation research, this exploratory project will develop student-centric cyber-physical systems for building science and structural analysis, and address the following questions: 1) How do students’ interest, motivation, and engagement vary? 2) How does student-centric cyber-physical systems affect student ability to sense and predict solutions to problems? 3) How does exposure to sensing technology and data science aspects of student-centric cyber-physical systems affect students’ perceptions of civil and building engineering, particularly the low/high tech nature of the field? The developed student-centric cyber-physical systems tools will be tested and assessed at two large public research universities. The project plans to generate theory to guide the transition for next-generation student-centric cyber-physical systems tools across multiple STEM fields. Lessons learned in the context of civil and building engineering can be shared with other fields, potentially leading to a broad national impact. The student-centric cyber-physical systems tools will also be used in outreach efforts at K-12 public schools. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Civil and Building Engineering (CBE) students often have limited active-learning experiences in classrooms, because the problems CBE addresses are large-scale, expensive, and usually not available locally for students to experience (e.g., civil & urban infrastructures). For example, CBE students usually learn concepts of structural behaviors or building science through textbooks, diagrams on whiteboards or computer screens, and problem sets. This abstract approach may build theoretical knowledge but affective outcomes, conceptual understanding, and ability to solve real-world problems are less than ideal. Moreover,  CBE programs in the US reported difficulties attracting and retaining students. Students perceive CBE as "low tech" compared to computer science, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, and other fields, hindering recruitment. However, civil and building engineers now employ cutting-edge technologies, sensors, and data to make our infrastructure "smart" through advances in Internet of Things. Retention is also an issue in CBE programs. Therefore, there is a critical need to improve CBE education in order to form the next generation of STEM professionals to address the nation's pressing infrastructure needs.

            To address this critical need, this project developed next-generation digital tools to improve teaching and learning in undergraduate CBE classes, and build awareness of CBE among K-12 students who might enroll engineering programs to address recruitment and retention. Following research and theory, active learning and embodied cognition strategies are implemented and studied in order to develop promising approaches to CBE education.

This project brings real-world problems in CBE into classrooms through interactive digital visualizations of important building and infrastructure systems that are driven by students' actions, using ubiquitous mobile devices (e.g., smartphones) as the platform. These student-centric cyber-physical systems (SCPS) are posited to have the following advantages:

●        They provide contextualized, active-learning instructional activities for CBE students, which should result in higher affective and cognitive outcomes;

●        They provide access to realistic simulated experiences with structures or buildings that are otherwise inaccessible to CBE students;

●        They rely on students' movements and actions to explore the behavior of systems;

●        They introduce students to sensor-based infrastructure modeling (with rapid advances in IoT) that is likely to be ever more common in CBE; and

●        They introduce sensing technology and data science for civil & building engineers.

Two student-centric cyber-physical systems (SCPS) were developed. These are mobile apps that students can interact with and use to complete their assignments and projects. The two SCPS were 1) Structural Analysis Integrated Learning (SAIL) and 2) Learn Building and were tested in CE325 Structural Analysis I at North Carolina State University and COSC461 Building Information Modeling Systems at Texas A&M University, respectively.

This implementation of the app with homework shows students not just attempting to derive equations but actually observing behavior of beams and relationships. This is positive progress since the purpose of the app is to help students improve engineering understanding and intuition and help them analyze problems and make decisions quickly. SAIL will help students who are blindly applying numbers into equations without realizing the end output does not make sense. The industry is having more and more black box tools for engineers and many of them rely on these tools. We need engineers who can quickly judge/verify whether the output from these Blackbox tools make sense or not. Moreover, this project demonstrated that the POE method effectively bridges theoretical knowledge with practical observation and explanation, helping students develop a deeper understanding of key concepts and gain valuable insights into real-world applications. The positive feedback and successful outcomes from this project suggest that the POE method has significant potential for scalability and could be expanded to other areas of the curriculum to further enhance student learning and engagement.

The overarching goal of this research project is to transform the perception of civil and building engineering from a "low tech" field to one that is technologically advanced and innovative. By leveraging affordable sensing technologies and interactive digital visualizations, we can make large-scale, real-world problems accessible to students in the classroom, thereby increasing their motivation and interest in the field. This project not only contributes to the improvement of STEM education but also holds the potential to have a broad national impact by influencing educational practices across multiple STEM disciplines.
